title: Entertaining Ourselves Back to Life
material: Entertaining Ourselves Back to Life The third book of the Lord of the Rings trilogy is titled The Return of the King; in it (spoilers ahead) the character Aragorn returns to unite humanity against a dire threat. The idea of a prophesied king reappearing and bringing his people together again against a formidable foe is common in literary history, from the overtold legend of King Arthur to the incomplete story of Jon Snow. Explore some of the following legends, then discuss with your team: why do such stories have such appeal? What political developments in today’s world might have similar causes? Horus | Yudhishthira | Jesus | Richard the Lionheart Charles II | Louis XVIII | Henry VII | Juan Carlos I The Hobbit | Prince Caspian | Kimba the White Lion When at first you don’t succeed, try and try again—and, likely as not, flop harder. Napoleon Bonaparte returned from exile in Elba as a self-reproclaimed emperor, only to drown in misfortune at Waterloo. Look into the following figures whose careers took off post-exile, then discuss with your team: why was their second wind better than their first? Can you think of other examples of individuals, like Napoleon, who attempted a comeback—but failed spectacularly? Albert Einstein | Leon Trotsky | Jimmy Carter | Friedrich Engels Dante | Confucius | Rodrigo Belmonte Malala Yousafzai | Sun Mu | Belarus Free Theatre | An-My Le “Funny when you're dead, how people start listenin'” quipped the 2010 hit song “If I Die Young”. Consider the other now-famous dead people below and discuss with your team: what is the best way to reignite someone’s legacy? Vincent van Gogh, for instance, only became famous after his death thanks to the people in his life. Should we focus more on studying the works of those who are still alive, or does a creator’s death make their creations more interesting in some way? Gregor Mendel | Alfred Wegener Emily Dickinson | Franz Kafka | Anne Frank Vivian Maier | Otis Redding | Jim Croce | Nick Drake “I did it again” isn’t always an oops; it’s often a plan. Many artists re-record and sometimes greatly revise and recreate their own past works. Taylor Swift’s new “Version(s)” of her old albums have set the charts on fire even though most of her songs are little-changed—but for some, her success has had consequences. Discuss with your team: what is the right time to re-release existing works, and to what degree should the original creator need to be involved? In 2023, electronic music artist Porter Robinson created the “Po-uta” voice bank to allow future artists to create songs using his voice. Check out this interview where he explains his motivations as well as the demonstration song “Humansongs”. Similarly, some Hollywood actors are creating digital clones of themselves with the help of AI—some to preserve their likeness for the future, others to accept multiple gigs at once. Explore these technologies with your team, then discuss with your team: when (and how much) does it matter whether an artwork is created by the artist themselves or their digital clone? For years, people have wondered what Beethoven’s tenth symphony—the “Unfinished”—would have sounded like if he had lived a little bit longer. Now, an AI has taken on the task, with substantial human involvement. Read about the effort, then compare the outcome to this earlier attempt by the composer Barry Cooper. Which seems more authentic to you—and which has more artistic value? Are there other unfinished works you would like to see completed in a similar way? Some people think a lot about the Roman Empire, but the songwriter Jorge Rivera-Herrans was more into ancient Greece. Explore the TikTok-documented story behind the creation of his EPIC: The Musical—which was inspired by Homer’s The Odyssey but blends modern genres, even video game music, and listen to at least this one example song (you’ll probably want to keep going): “Wouldn’t You Like”. Afterward, discuss with your team: should more creators communicate openly with the public while developing new works of fiction, theater, and art? Should we have done that with these outlines?

additional-material.name: If I Die Young
additional-material.text:
The official music video for "If I Die Young" by The Band Perry, released on May 28, 2010, has garnered significant attention, amassing over 264 million views. The song, characterized by its poignant lyrics and emotional delivery, explores themes of mortality, the fleeting nature of life, and the legacy one leaves behind. It resonates deeply with listeners, particularly those who have experienced loss, as it reflects on the impact of a young life cut short and the desire for remembrance.

The narrative within the song is conveyed through a blend of storytelling and imagery, illustrating the life of a young person who contemplates their own death and the reactions of those left behind. The lyrics evoke a sense of longing and introspection, emphasizing the importance of cherishing life and the memories created with loved ones. The chorus, with its memorable lines, encapsulates the bittersweet nature of youth and the desire for significance, even in death.

The music video complements the song's themes by visually representing the emotional weight of the lyrics. It features scenes that depict both the vibrancy of life and the sorrow of loss, enhancing the viewer's connection to the song. The Band Perry's performance, combined with the evocative visuals, creates a powerful experience that resonates with a wide audience, particularly those who have faced similar experiences of grief and remembrance.

Overall, "If I Die Young" stands out not only as a commercial success but also as a meaningful exploration of life's fragility. Its enduring popularity is a testament to its emotional depth and the universal themes it addresses, making it a significant piece within the country music genre and beyond. The song continues to inspire discussions about loss, legacy, and the importance of living fully.

additional-material.name: the people in his life
additional-material.text:
Jo van Gogh-Bonger played a pivotal role in the posthumous fame of her brother-in-law, Vincent van Gogh. After the death of her husband, Theo, in 1891, Jo found herself responsible for their young son and a vast collection of Vincent's artworks. Despite the challenges of her situation, including financial instability and societal pressures, Jo was determined to promote Vincent's art. Her commitment stemmed from a deep personal connection to both her husband and Vincent, as well as a belief in the value of his work.

Jo's efforts to elevate Vincent's status as an artist were multifaceted. She organized exhibitions, collaborated with art dealers, and actively sought to place his works in prominent galleries. Her strategic partnerships and relentless advocacy were crucial in introducing Vincent's art to a broader audience. Jo's dedication was not merely professional; it was deeply emotional, as she sought to honor the legacy of her late husband and his brother, whose genius had been largely unrecognized during his lifetime.

The impact of Jo's work was profound, leading to a significant shift in the perception of Vincent van Gogh's art. Over time, his paintings gained immense popularity, and he became one of the most celebrated artists in history. Jo's efforts not only secured Vincent's legacy but also transformed the art world, as she challenged the norms of her time regarding the promotion of artists and their work.

Ultimately, Jo van Gogh-Bonger's role in making Vincent famous highlights the importance of personal dedication and advocacy in the arts. Her story serves as a reminder of how individual commitment can shape cultural narratives and influence the recognition of artistic talent. Through her perseverance, Jo ensured that Vincent van Gogh's contributions to art would be remembered and celebrated for generations to come.

additional-material.name: consequences
additional-material.text:
Taylor Swift's re-recording project, initiated in 2019 after her original master recordings were sold without her consent, has significantly impacted the music industry and prompted record labels to reconsider their contractual practices. Swift's objective was to reclaim ownership of her music and diminish the value of the original recordings. Her re-recorded albums have not only outperformed the originals but have also propelled her to unprecedented levels of success, including becoming a billionaire in 2023. This success has led major record labels to impose stricter re-recording restrictions on new artists, requiring them to wait significantly longer—up to thirty years—before they can re-record their music.

The article outlines the complexities of copyright law as it pertains to master recordings and the traditional dynamics between artists and record labels. Under U.S. copyright law, record labels typically own the rights to master recordings, which creates a power imbalance favoring the labels. Swift's journey illustrates this dynamic, as her initial contract with Big Machine Records granted the label ownership of her first six albums. After leaving Big Machine and signing with Republic Records, Swift regained ownership of her future master recordings, allowing her to pursue her re-recording project without violating copyright laws.

Swift's re-recording strategy has not only been commercially successful but has also served as a catalyst for broader discussions about artists' rights and ownership in the music industry. The article notes that while re-recording is not a new concept, Swift's success has brought renewed attention to the issue, influencing how new artists negotiate their contracts. For instance, artists like Olivia Rodrigo have sought to retain control over their master recordings, inspired by Swift's experiences. This shift indicates a growing awareness among artists regarding their rights and the importance of negotiating favorable terms in their contracts.

In light of these developments, the article argues that record labels should adopt a more collaborative approach with artists rather than imposing lengthy re-recording restrictions. The changing landscape of the music industry, particularly with the rise of digital platforms, has diminished artists' reliance on labels for success. By treating artists as partners and fostering mutually beneficial relationships, labels could adapt to the evolving industry dynamics and support artists in achieving their creative and commercial goals.

additional-material.name: this interview
additional-material.text:
In a recent interview, Porter Robinson discusses his experience with the VOCALOID voice bank "Po-uta," which he created using his own voice. Robinson expresses excitement about this opportunity, noting that VOCALOID music significantly influenced his album _Nurture_. He highlights the impact of Japanese artists like DECO*27 and KZ/Livetune on his musical style, particularly their use of melancholic chord progressions. The process of using the voice bank inspired him to approach music creation differently, focusing on syllables and meanings in a more integrated manner than his usual method of starting with auto-tuned vocals.

Robinson elaborates on the thematic elements of the demo song featuring Po-uta, which explores the relationship between an artificial mind and its creator. He aims to evoke feelings of grief and contemplation regarding the ethical dilemmas posed by AI, framing the narrative as a child mourning a parent. This emotional lens, while not necessarily realistic, is intended to resonate with human experiences, emphasizing the artistic intent behind the work.

Reflecting on his journey with VOCALOID, Robinson recounts his early encounters with the technology, particularly through the character Hatsune Miku and the English VOCALOID Avanna. He acknowledges the significance of these experiences in shaping his music, particularly in his 2014 album _Worlds_, where he sought to capture the unique emotional qualities of digital voices. He appreciates the power of vocals in music, noting their ability to convey both melody and meaning, and views VOCALOID as a natural evolution of voice manipulation technologies.

Looking ahead, Robinson expresses optimism about the future of VOCALOID, anticipating advancements that will enhance its flexibility and realism. He hopes that creators will embrace Po-uta's unique voice and produce original works that explore its character. Ultimately, he encourages artists to use available tools to express their innermost ideas, emphasizing the importance of creativity in the face of technological evolution.

additional-material.name: Humansongs
additional-material.text:
The video titled "Po-uta (Porter Robinson) - Humansongs (YAMAHA 'VOCALOID6 Po-uta' demonstration song)" features a demonstration of the new Vocaloid software, VOCALOID6, showcasing its capabilities through a song created by musician Porter Robinson. Released on March 6, 2023, the video has garnered over a million views, highlighting the interest in both Robinson's work and the advancements in Vocaloid technology. The song serves as a demonstration of the Po-uta Vocaloid, which is designed to emulate Robinson's vocal style, thus creating a unique blend of human and synthetic musical expression.

The lyrics of "Humansongs" reflect themes of emotion, existence, and legacy, resonating deeply with listeners. The song's narrative suggests a poignant relationship between the Vocaloid and its creator, exploring the idea of a digital persona continuing to convey human emotions and experiences even after the creator's absence. This emotional depth is a hallmark of Robinson's songwriting, and it is particularly impactful given the context of a Vocaloid, which traditionally lacks human emotional expression.

The video not only showcases the song but also serves as a promotional tool for the new Vocaloid software, demonstrating its potential to create music that feels authentic and relatable. The use of Po-uta as a representation of Robinson's voice signifies a full-circle moment in his career, as he has transitioned from a human artist to a creator of a Vocaloid that embodies his musical essence. This development raises questions about the future of music production and the role of technology in artistic expression.

Overall, "Humansongs" exemplifies the intersection of technology and artistry, illustrating how Vocaloid software can be used to create emotionally resonant music. The song's reception indicates a strong interest in Vocaloid culture and its evolution, as well as a growing appreciation for the emotional narratives that can be conveyed through synthetic voices. The implications of this technology extend beyond mere novelty, suggesting a future where digital and human artistry coexist and enrich one another.

additional-material.name: digital clones of themselves
additional-material.text:
Heather Tal Murphy’s *Slate* article **“Actors Are Already Selling Digital Clones of Themselves for $500. Are Stars Next?”** examines how **AI-driven digital doubles** are already transforming entertainment and labor — and why the technology’s rise has Hollywood unions and performers on edge. The piece blends firsthand accounts, emerging industry trends, and ethical concerns to show that what once seemed like a sci-fi scenario has already entered the marketplace.

It begins with the story of **Devin Finley**, a New York voice actor who allowed a company called **Hour One** to create and license his virtual replica for $500. Using a short filming session and AI modeling, the company produced a lifelike avatar that can appear in corporate videos or ads—speaking multiple languages, never aging, and continuing to “work” indefinitely. Finley found the idea both unsettling and liberating: a way to earn money passively, but also to surrender control over his likeness. Companies such as **Hour One** and **Synthesia** now produce thousands of such “virtual human” videos for corporate clients, signaling a fast-expanding industry that sits outside traditional union protections.

Murphy then situates this phenomenon within a broader **Hollywood labor crisis**. As studios explore AI’s potential to recreate or simulate performers’ likenesses, unions like **SAG-AFTRA** are pushing to define clear rules on consent, compensation, and usage limits. The issue loomed large during the 2023–2024 writers’ and actors’ strikes, reflecting wider anxieties about automation and creative control. Startups such as **Runway** and **Brask Doubles** already offer tools to generate video content from text or swap celebrity faces onto body doubles, often used in advertising when stars like Lionel Messi or Kylian Mbappé can’t be present. These technologies reduce production costs and timelines—making synthetic likenesses a tempting shortcut for studios and brands.

The article breaks down several **concrete uses** of AI cloning already in play:

* **Advertising stand-ins**, where brands use AI-masked doubles of celebrities.
* **“Synthespians”**, digital overlays that rely on real body doubles but use AI for the face or voice.
* **Advanced dubbing**, in which AI adjusts lip movements to match new languages.
* **Corporate avatars**, used in marketing, training, and instructional videos—cheap, controllable, and endlessly reusable.

Murphy concludes that while today’s technology still depends on human stand-ins for realism, the **erosion of performer control** is already underway. Licensing one’s digital twin may soon become as routine as signing a brand deal, but with deeper implications: once an avatar exists, it can speak, move, and act without its human’s consent or oversight. The looming question, she writes, is not whether AI clones will reshape entertainment—but **who will own and profit from the human image in the age of synthetic identity.**

additional-material.name: taken on the task
additional-material.text:
The Beethoven X project centers on the completion of Beethoven's 10th Symphony, which remained unfinished at the time of his death in 1827. Utilizing 40 existing sketches left by Beethoven, a collaborative team of experts in machine learning and musicology has developed an artificial intelligence system to compose the missing sections of the symphony. This innovative endeavor aims to bring Beethoven's final work to life, culminating in a live premiere performed by the Beethoven Orchestra Bonn.

The project is structured around three primary narratives: the life and legacy of Ludwig van Beethoven, the creative process of transforming sketches into a completed symphony, and the human elements involved in the project, including rehearsals and recordings. The documentary accompanying the project highlights these narratives, emphasizing Beethoven's status as a cultural icon and the emotional resonance of his music, as expressed by various artists, including Billy Joel.

The collaboration involves notable institutions such as Telekom, The Mindshift, and Artrendex, alongside contributions from experts affiliated with Harvard, Cambridge, and Rutgers Universities. This multidisciplinary approach underscores the intersection of technology and the arts, showcasing how AI can enhance the creative process while respecting the original artistic vision of Beethoven.

The project not only aims to complete a historical piece of music but also seeks to engage contemporary audiences with Beethoven's work in a novel way. By merging AI technology with classical music, Beethoven X represents a significant cultural moment, inviting reflection on the implications of artificial intelligence in creative fields and the enduring legacy of one of history's greatest composers.

additional-material.name: this earlier attempt
additional-material.text:
The YouTube video titled "Symphony No.10 in E-flat major - Ludwig van Beethoven / Barry Cooper" features a performance by the London Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Wyn Morris. This symphony, which Beethoven began composing before completing his Ninth Symphony, remains largely unfinished. The work on Symphony No. 10 began in earnest around 1822 and continued until Beethoven's death in 1827, but only the first movement was developed in detail. The sketches for the symphony are fragmented and scattered across various manuscripts, making it challenging to ascertain Beethoven's complete intentions for the piece.

Barry Cooper, a musicologist with a focus on Beethoven's works, undertook the task of reconstructing the first movement based on the available sketches. He identified over 50 sketches, which, while incomplete, provided substantial thematic material. Cooper's approach involved filling in gaps and orchestrating the movement in a style consistent with Beethoven's known works. The reconstruction process revealed around 250 bars of sketches, although many were repetitive or contradictory, leading to the use of thematic material in various ways to create a coherent performance version.

The resulting performance aims to offer a glimpse into what Beethoven might have envisioned for his Tenth Symphony. While Cooper's completion is not a definitive representation of Beethoven's intentions, it provides a valuable interpretation that allows audiences to experience the music in a way that the original sketches alone could not convey. The performance is characterized by its adherence to Beethoven's stylistic elements, though it may reflect more of his middle period rather than the late style typically associated with his later works.

Overall, the video serves as both a musical performance and an exploration of Beethoven's creative process, highlighting the challenges and possibilities inherent in reconstructing unfinished compositions. It invites listeners to engage with Beethoven's legacy and consider the implications of his incomplete works within the broader context of classical music history.

additional-material.name: TikTok-documented story
additional-material.text:
"Epic: The Musical" is a concept album created by Jorge Rivera-Herrans that adapts the story of Odysseus from Homer's "The Odyssey." This adaptation emerges amidst a resurgence of interest in Greek mythology in popular culture, with works like Madeline Miller's "Song of Achilles" and Disney's "Percy Jackson" gaining traction. Rivera-Herrans' musical focuses on Odysseus' tumultuous journey home to his wife and son, exploring themes of morality and the supernatural, while aiming to bring renewed attention to "The Odyssey," which often gets overshadowed by "The Iliad."

The project began as a passion project in 2019, evolving from Rivera-Herrans' college dorm room. Influenced by music and storytelling from video games and anime, he began sharing snippets of the musical on TikTok in early 2021, engaging his audience with insights into his creative process. By March 2022, he presented a seminar at the Goodspeed Festival of New Musicals, announcing that the musical would be released in chapters, or "sagas." The first saga, "The Troy Saga," was released in December 2022, with a total of nine sagas planned, seven of which have been released to date.

The musical has cultivated a growing fanbase, uniting diverse online communities of animators, actors, musicians, and writers. Rivera-Herrans emphasizes the importance of enjoyment and collaboration among the cast and crew, which is evident in the playful behind-the-scenes content shared on social media. This sense of camaraderie contributes to the musical's appeal, fostering a vibrant community around the project.

Musically, "Epic" is described as a hauntingly brilliant work that intricately weaves together themes from its source material, maintaining fidelity to the essence of "The Odyssey." It does not shy away from the darker elements of the original text, instead highlighting the supernatural aspects that are central to the narrative. The latest saga, "The Wisdom Saga," introduces Telemachus, Odysseus's son, and further explores the kingdom of Ithaca. While currently available only as a concept album, the potential for a staged performance remains a point of anticipation for fans.

additional-material.name: Wouldn’t You Like
additional-material.text:
The video "Wouldn't You Like - Epic: The Musical (Lyric Video) (Hermes Version)" features a musical number from the production "Epic: The Musical," which is centered around themes from mythology, particularly focusing on the character Hermes. This version of the song is presented as a lyric video, allowing viewers to follow along with the words as they are sung. The musical itself is known for its modern interpretation of classic mythological tales, blending humor and contemporary elements with traditional narratives.

The song captures Hermes' playful and mischievous nature, reflecting his role as the messenger god in Greek mythology. The lyrics suggest a whimsical invitation to explore the world and its pleasures, embodying Hermes' character traits of trickery and charm. The upbeat tempo and engaging melody contribute to the overall lively atmosphere of the piece, making it appealing to a broad audience, including fans of musical theater and mythology.

The video has garnered significant attention, with hundreds of thousands of views, indicating a strong interest in both the musical and the character of Hermes. This popularity may be attributed to the unique blend of humor, catchy music, and the relatable themes of adventure and curiosity that resonate with viewers. The production's approach to storytelling through song allows for a fresh take on familiar myths, making them accessible and entertaining for contemporary audiences.

Overall, "Wouldn't You Like" serves as a vibrant representation of "Epic: The Musical," showcasing the creative potential of musical theater to reinterpret and revitalize ancient stories. The lyric video format enhances viewer engagement, inviting them to connect with the material on a deeper level while enjoying the performance.
